description:
This used to be our go-to Chinese restaurant when my mom lived in the City. Sadly, since she moved away several years ago, we seldom get a chance to visit.
However, when the SO and I walked in we were greeted with recognition and smiles. The server (Waylan) even remembered what we used to order! (Whaaaat?) I had the usual (unusual) Vegetable Egg Foo Yung made with egg whites only and the SO ordered Pepper Steak. We split a bowl of BBQ pork won ton soup and steamed white rice. Kenny (the boss) produced a plate of Shrimp Stuffed Eggplant for us to try (on the house) and we asked for an order of Chinese Chicken Salad to take home.  
The Egg Foo Yung made with egg whites was fantastic as always. Most restaurants won't attempt it, it's too hard to make. The SO ate the Pepper Steak with his eyes closed he was so happy. He said it was tender, flavorful and better than any place else. The Shrimp Stuffed Eggplant was amazing! Kenny said it was new and had a Thai style sauce; a little hot, a little sweet. Absolutely delicious. We had been jonesing for the Superior Won Ton soup; the broth is delicate, yet flavorful, the won tons are a decent size (made with lots of shrimp) and we love the baby bok choy and slices of charsiu.
Chinese Chicken Salad to go? After a lunch like that you want something light for dinner. Crunchy, tangy and full of tender pieces of chicken, yummy!
For a clean, affordable, SF neighborhood  restaurant serving delicious Chinese food this is the place to come.
Thanks to Kenny, Waylan and the rest of the Superior Palace staff for the spectacular meal and the warm welcome. We'll be back!
author: Toki N.

description:
If i could give 0 stars I would...

This establishment the food is not bad typical chinese family style, waiters are nice.

I've come to this establishment quite often with friends and family so I can say that im a regular. Prices are decent and I grew up eating these types of meals. I usually do not write negative reviews but this one goes off the top. Its a typical night eating with my girlfriend and other friend everything is going well, were having a good time eating food drinking a beer. Then the bill comes. Everything was correct and generally i am a generous tipper, The bill comes out to $98 and some change. I Throw down $120 and sit there packing up the leftovers and finishing my bill, 5 mins of still waiting for my change i grow tiresome and asked the restaurant owner hey can i get my change back? she looks at me confused and im like we clearly paid overly to expect some change back. Waiter pulls me to the side hey its ok i will get you your change. Owner still looks confused, Like what in her right mind does she automatcially think im tipping $22 out of a $98 bill?? crazy much will not be returning to this establishment and i warn you also so you do not get ripped off by these people. They will sell you dead seafood for the high also if they can get the slip.
author: Timothy C.

description:
Average Chinese restaurant that won't break the bank. This place is good for large groups.

My family likes to come to this place to have dinner together. Parking can be hard to find.

Service is decent and food is good. I enjoy coming here with my family. I probably would not come here if I was with a small group.
author: Jessica S.

description: I'm giving it 1 start for fast service. That's all this place deserves. This is probably the worst Chinese food I ever had after living in SF for 30 years. Spending over $65 for a dinner for two for nasty tasting everything is just unfair. The wonton soup literally had 4 dumplings and 2 leaves of bok choy. Sweet and sour pork was just thin slices of pig fat covered in heavy breading. Egg rolls were dark brown and looked like they have suffered a bad case of bubonic plague. Not so fresh, dry tasting fried rice and slimy beef broccoli. Oh, whatever you do - do not eat the peanuts they serve you with the tea and the menu. You'll thank me later. Unfortunately, I think they put those same peanuts in the Kung pao chicken I asked to take home. This is horrid food.
author: Laurie P.

description: Came here for my girlfriend's Chinese New Years dinner with her huge family.  The good thing is that they can accommodate a large group.  Other people wrote that it can get buys here at times, but the time that I came was not that busy.  It does not look like the most cleanest of places, but what do you expect from a super Chinese place.  The food tastes good, but I'm sure it's heavily salted and possibly even MSG'd.
author: Richard L.

description: Ate here with wife and ordered the BBQ pork egg foo young for 12 bucks and did not see the meat except for bits of red.  Total rip off place.  Spending my money elsewhere next time.  Told the lady boss but she just did not care.  Furthermore, the fried fish was so over cooked that the fish  became tasteless and more like sawdust.  Most likely it was precooked and was refried.  Terrible service too, cause they will just bring out the food and disappear.  Ee use be regular customer but this has changed our status.
author: Jesse C.

description: My go to place for lunch with my crew.  Great salt pepper pork and butter melon with eggs.  Service is fast, cheap with good food!  Try the sweet hot chicken wings!  Fried oyster is also a must.
author: Curtis L.

description:
Tasty dishes, value for your money and a great variety of offerings: from home style dishes & familiar Cantonese daily fare like chow mein, fried rice, to banquet offerings. there are set menus for family style meals and banquets.

Friendly service, generous home style soup with meals.
author: E W.

description: Very busy restaurant due to small size location. Parking extremely hard to find-street parking only in Outer Richmond District. Be prepared for long wait times especially during the weekend. Great time to drive very close to the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: A L.

description:
3.5 stars. 

Food = good but a bit more greasy than I'd like it. You were warned. 

Tabletop pork bone soup with mustard greens and carrots = delicious start.  

Potstickers = good. The skin is on the thinner side but the filling is excellent. $5.50

Spicy fried chicken wings = excellent flavorful, sticky sauce wings. We ate them all because saucy, fried wings ate never quite the same as leftovers (soggy). $7.50

Mixed vegetables = $7.50

Shrimp with scrambled eggs over rice = good. White sauce base with airy eggs and scallions but not much flavor. On their menu, this dish is usually over ho fun but I requested rice.  (I keep looking for white sauce based shrimp with lobster sauce. They do have that particular dish but it's black bean based which I like, but not what I'm looking for. I may concede to not finding it again in the Bay Area, and just make it myself again.)  $8.50.

Coke = $2.00. 

Service = friendly enough. You'll probably get better service with Chinese speaking skills and find out what's off menu.

Prices = reasonable. Dinner for two came out to $33...
author: Fannie S.

description: I had a horrible experience this evening.  My family and I patron there regularly, so tonight we went for father's day dinner early at 5p when the restaurant wasn't crowded.  We ordered a bunch of entrees and they food came fairly quickly.  Midway through we still didn't get our soup, waiters were busy. Our noodles tasted old.  the old lady, owner came and snatched the platter and mouthed off it was fresh and walked off.  She came back and asked us to order another noodle entree.  We placed the order.  the new replacement noodles came and we were confused because we didn't ask for a replacement so the owner said it was complimentary.  we never got the pan fried noodle platter she insisted we order. That never came.  our check came and all in Chinese and the bad noodles were crossed off. the owner charged us as we had 8 entrees and charged for 9 items.  I flagged her down. She denied comping us, yet the item on the bill was crossed off but not the price.  She paused then snatched the bill and mouthed off again that we didn't have to eat it. I was shocked.  She adjusted the bill and slammed it down.  As I was leaving, i thanked her and she mouthed off again and wouldn't let up.  I had it. I told her it was not right giving us bad food and then promised it free, then charged us and we had horrible service way before the crowd came, so she had the nerve to be rude and I stated my parents patron there weekly. She couldn't look me in the eye. I won't ever eat there again.  She disrespect customers and I'm not going to give her business.
author: Lillian W.

description: Decent place for Chinese food. It's close to my brother's place so it's convenient. In a city known for its authentic Chinese food, I wouldn't put this near the top of the charts. The banquet dinner is pretty good, though. It had pretty much everything: Honey walnut shrimp, fish, lobster, noodles (which were my favorite dish), vegetables, soup. It's a lot of food designed to feed big groups of people.
author: Henry T.

description:
Chinese restaurants get such a bad rep. Unfair, but typical restaurant stereotype is how it is. However, as un-kept and old as it looks from the outside, the food is pretty legit. I've come here on multiple occasions now that I think this place finally deserves some Fifi love. 

It's a great family restaurant and it's nice to see get together dinners held. Whether you're in for a simple weekly dinner or a family reunion, the food ain't bad. For a typical dish, they cook it well. Served to your table hot from the fresh and with enough "wok heat" as we like to say it. The portions are great for family style with enough to doggy bag. They also have seafood, too! Crab, lobster, shrimp, fish, etc etc. The best part is that the price ain't hyped up either. It's at a reasonable price that probably costs you about the same as if you were to buy and cook at home yourself. 

Side story: For my dad's early birthday dinner, we ordered a 5.5lb Alaskan King Crab at the price of $25/lb. Now, $25/lb might make you go O_____O, but really, it's a lot less than other places. All I can say was that dish was finger licking tasty. Literally. 

I will usually avoid Chinese restaurants, but there's something about this place that I feel okay coming. Perhaps the food seems true to its Chinese roots. Or maybe it's just the best bang for your buck.
author: Fiona L.

description:
Not a palace exactly.  But the ears here are cheap
And no roach approached me as the health cleanliness warnings did pop up on Yelp.

Service is horrible here waiting for my food 40 minutes.  When the food came it was sub par.
Only thing good here was my clay pot chicken with eggplant and chicken with salted fish.

Potsticker was low quality and greasy.  Black cod was rushed and cold at center for 1/2 of the order.
Getting a simple box was also a non event... Sigh
author: David H.

description:
With high hopes and a cheery Chinese New Year attitude, my family and I decided to pick up an order of fried rice for my grandma. This was always one of her favorite Chinese restaurants by her house and she was a frequent visitor. However, over the past few months we have noticed that the prices are changing depending on whom you pick up orders from. Instead of the normal $10.00 price for an order of scallop fried rice, the price this time was $14.00. I asked if the prices went up, the cashier replied no. 

Please keep your prices consistent, instead of changing prices based on the customer.
author: Brin L.

description:
Now I'm all for not judging a restaurant because sometimes they make the most bomb ass food even if they aren't up to par. My fam and I came here last night per the recommendation of my uncle, so I didn't even yelp this place. 

The spread was great. We had peking duck baos, fried sticky rice, yummy cooked veggies, delicious eggplant dish, etc. It was a great way to start off the new year. With those new years resolutions, a girl can't help but be drawn to their complimentary Chinese chicken salad. Load it up I said, munching away happily...

Yeah I didn't wake up so happy. You can tell my stomach to stop bloating, cramping and help haul my ass off the bathroom floor. Now I don't need to go into other details about how food poisoning works. But eat here at your own risk. I felt obliged to be a cautionary tale to unsuspecting custo- .... sorry had to run to the bathroom.
author: Mindy X.

description:
Delicious!! As a party of seven, we got to try a great variety of the dishes here. The portions are pretty large, so coming in a big group is the only way to try a lot on the menu. Pretty much the whole menu is under $10 (excluding the seafood specialties), and the portions are huge. I saw the table next to us ordered some kind of saucy entree over rice, and I could swear that could feed a person for a good 5 meals. 

-----FOOD-----
We started with a complimentary shredded lettuce and peanut chicken salad that I believe is served upon request. They gave us a generous portion enough for all of us, with a lightly sweet and savory dressing. Really refreshing and well executed for a simple salad.

We ordered mostly based off the server's recommendations, which included their renowned seafood specialties: 石九公 fish two ways (live fish made into a soup and a stir fry) and boiled 珊瑚虾 (the texture of this shrimp meat is better than lobster). We also had 清蒸牛栏汤 (super tender beef in a light soup reminiscent of pho broth), 金沙南瓜 (fried salted egg yolk battered pumpkin), honey chicken wings (these are AMAZING) mixed mushroom stir fry, stir fried pea sprouts, and probably more that I can't remember. Everything was really good, but I'd say the beef and the wings are must orders. Best wings EVER and I can't believe I'm recommending wings at a Chinese restaurant. Trust me, the skin is so crispy and sweet and the inside so juicy and perfectly tender. 

-----INTERIOR-----
The place got quite busy at lunch time and the dining space is cramped in the side room. Three tables for large parties and the chairs are arranged so that you're pretty much back to back with the person at the next table. 

-----SERVICE-----
I usually expect subpar service at Chinese restaurants, so I was pleasantly surprised by our courteous waiters. Our server came by to help switch our dirty plates halfway through the meal, and helped us clear our finished dishes each time a new dish was brought.
author: Lily T.

description:
I've been coming here for years and this is always the spot for hubs' grandparents birthday dinners. The place is a bit cramped and the bathrooms are rather gross but the food is good. The set menu includes the cold platter, chicken, veggie dishes, soup and noodles. I love their noodles which are dry (meaning no sauce, not dehydrated) but pack flavor. Either that or I just love noodles. I would say both.

Parking around the neighborhood is rather challenging but keep circling. Something will open up.
author: Julie L.

description: Large Chinese food joint perfect for family dinners. Food quality is better than take out Chinese food with a variety of unique dishes including fukian fried rice as well as the usual honey walnut shrimp. I have also had the vegetarian chow fun and the eggplant here. It's my go to Chinese spot because it's close and open until 9:30. Downside is cash only up until $20. It's annoying to be forced to by another dish even if it's dinner for 1 (*cue sex and the city episode*)
author: Linda L.

description: Bad customer service. They overcharged me on the bill so I let the manager know. Took a while for them to correct their mistake. After they fixed it, manager just dropped the bill down on the table without so much as a glance. Very rude.
author: Allan C.

description:
We were heading to SFO for dropoff and decided to go for Korean at Hans.....drive right up in front and it was closed on all Wednesdays.....what a disappointment....

We then hit this corner....and I am thinking Little Henrys....could do Italian anytime....but my friends NOT....so we headed across the street.....

Don't get me wrong...I have been here several times...food is always good....and prices reasonable

We ordered oxtails in claypot....very good
bittermelon and ribs.....best
egg and oyster pancake...but this time I added a twist...choy po...its a preserved veggie which gives it a nice crunch....

very good
author: Leslie Y.

description: Cheap, tasty food. Tables felt kinda sticky. Service was quick enough. Big variety on the menu. Water tasted weird.
author: Kelly G.

description:
Good food. Horrible service.

I come here on occasion because this place serves the best Singapore noodles on this side of Balboa. But whether or not the place is busy, the workers there always act as if helping you is a burden. If they don't brush you off with "Later, " they just flat out ignore you. And when giving you change, they slam it on the counter instead of placing it in your hand. The gentleman at least cracks a smile.
author: Di P.

description:
Local Cantonese style chinese food.
$5 rice plates - enough said...
Good service. Many families are present so this is a good sign of their local reputation.
Go for it...
author: David H.

description: I'm not scared of no poor health safety score! That's where you get the good flavor from! I come here every Wednesday with my family and get the pork chops, green beans, cod, chicken and chow fun. All are pretty decent but I must have the pork chops and green beans. They have some off days but the hit days are great
author: Dylan L.

description: I would say this is a pretty average Chinese restaurant in the outer richmond. They mostly cater to larger groups and have a pretty extensive menu. My hubby works close by at the VA so he'll usually bring us home take out from here or on occasion we'll dine in. We usually go with the broccoli beef and beef chow fun which are slightly above average tasting here. They will even let you order the lunch prices plates for dinner (which I'm always getting since you can't beat the price!) Portion sizes are big, beef isn't too chewy and the amount of sauce is just right. We have also tried the ox tail clay pot which was good and the lobster chow mein which had tasty sauce and a good amount of lobster for the price. Service can be a bit slow but they do offer free soup and dessert at the end. Parking can be tough so expect to circle around for a while. Good thing they are open on Christmas and New Years,  or we wouldn't have anywhere to eat!
author: Petra S.

description:
The wait for the food was insane! We tried asking one of the servers to check on our order and he replied saying "almost." However, after his reply, the food still took an extra 30mins to comeout, and they only brought out soup and one of the six dishes we ordered. We had to wait another 10mins for a second dish, and even another 10mins for the rest.

Furthermore, the food is only decent. Quality and taste is just like any other chinese food you will find at a chinese resturant.
author: Eric T.

description: I was looking for geoduck soup for my brothers bday dinner. It was fresh and delicious. They made two dishes with it. A soup and stir fry! I'll be back for more!
author: Lee J.

description: Very ho-hum place. Menu looked like it had the right food and the prices looked good, but all the dishes were bland and had no flavor. Not really worth going to.
author: C C.

description:
Snuck into town for a quick lunch after visiting a busy museum nearby. Jumped on yelp to see what was around: 3.5 stars seemed ok and safe enough. When we looked at the menu we were shocked. It's literally $5 for a sit-down Chinese lunch including soup and tea. And the food was tasty. Service wasn't anything special, but that was to be expected. 
Seriously, for $5, go here, eat, drink tea, and be happy.
author: Honest G.

description: check out the  accumulation of cigarette butts just outside the restaurant , especially around the corner on 37th avenue, where the kitchen-crew takes their breaks sitting on milkgrates and smoking ...there are butts everywhere. It is disgusting. I would never go again, where the folks working there have such a low regard for their neighborhood and healthregulations .  Maybe the SF Health dept should do an inspection  of this place soon.
author: Walter O.

description:
The good news is that the prices are very reasonable.

That is about the end of the good news.

My dad got the seafood soup, which he said was bland and heavy on the calamari and bok choi.

I got the kung pao chicken and rice lunch.  It came with the house soup, which was really bland.  The kung pao was also bland.  I added the hot oil that they put on the table which made it palatable.

Our bill was $12 plus tax, which is very cheap for how much food you get.  So, if you are looking for quantity over quality, you are in luck.  With so much great Chinese food in the Richmond district, I would stay away.
author: Gary A.

description:
Great value!

Good traditional Chinese steamed rock cod.  That was my favorite dish.  We also go the taro and port belly....mmmm.    I can't recall the other dishes we got as they were just mediocre, so I think the dishes are hit or miss.  They also served a very good complimentary dessert: taro with tapioca.  

Overall a great value for decent food.  I would come back again.
author: Jaching H.

description: Came here on a Sunday and had the King Crab for dinner which was cooked really good! As you know the king crab is big and pricey but they cook it in a lot of different ways which is pretty cool. Like they steam the legs over clear noodles with a garlic sauce, they deep fried another portion of the legs with pumpkin in a salted egg yolk batter, they also use the head to do this steamed egg thing which was really good. But my favorite was the one in the salted egg yolk because it was crispy and really flavorful. We also had the melon soup which is a broth cooked in a melon, chicken salad, deep fried pigeons, chicken sticky rice thing which were all really good too. They do get pack really fast for dinner on the weekends so it's a good idea to make a reservation since the place isn't that big either. The customer service is okay but unless you know the workers and all and speak Chinese then it's a tad bit better. Overall the food was excellent and the service was good.
author: Maybeline C.

description: Quick, fast, get-in/get-out, no hassle.  Good tasting food.  Hope these small family businesses keep thriving!
author: Hank L.

description: A neighborhood Chinese restaurant where the food is much better than the decors might indicate. Very good seafood. They also offer many budget dishes.
author: Chung L.

description:
Came here over the weekend with one of my Pals and my Husband. My Pal had mentioned this was a really good place and she was right! 
We ordered a sizzling beef dish with sweet and sour chicken and a side of "Superior Palace's Chow Mein." My friend got a $5 lunch special. $5! Super cheap! 

The food:
Sweet and Sour chicken had the right balance of sweet and sour.. not overwhelming.
Sizzling Beef platter was so good! The pieces of steak were tender and seasoned perfectly accompanied with the sizzling veggies. A must try!
Chow Mein: Not greasy and I was intrigued with all the ingredients, I think there was Calamari in there along with other proteins.

Parking was good.
We were seated quickly.
The decor was a little plain but the food was good.

We will be coming here again!
author: Melissa H.

description: POS place..... Anyone that come here will be playing the waiting game when trying to get service. the "manager" was hella rude when we asked her to get a cup of water. telling us to hold on blah blah and I over heard her taking shit about us in Chinese. Was so tempted to just get up and walk out but the order was already placed. the food tasted hella salty even for a Chinese place, and I had to get them to refill the water after every plate. Stray away from this place unless you like the shit food and service.
author: Aaron C.

description:
$5 lunch specials ftw! And all the food is really good too. I love places with great food and great prices. And it's very in character for the neighborhood. 

I got the Mongolian beef, and while it wasn't the best Mongolian beef I've ever had, it was definitely in the top 10%. Savory, a nice but not overwhelming combination of spices, well cooked, and served with more than enough rice on the side to use all the delicious sauce. You'll have to add your own sririacha (or specifically request it spicy) if you want it to be hot.  

Add that to the great prices and I'll definitely be returning. When I do, expect more reviews of more items.
author: Chris S.

description:
I just had lunch in there because they had reasonable lunch special which is $5-6.50

We ordered two lunch and one side dish - one seafood with rice and broccoli beef with rice. The waiter asked me American broccoli or Chinese broccoli.. So I asked Chinese . He didn't say anything about extra.

Taste was good.
It wasn't my first time visit . In fact I brought my family last week also even though we live in downtown.

When we asked the check, it was funny
The price was added over $1 each dishes so I asked why the price is different. What they said is "Chinese broccoli is Very Expensive so added $1.50"

WTF...
If u go to any Chinese market u can buy bunch for $ 1.50

And the waiter kept telling us he was new.
Other guy kept talking Chinese to us but he was our
Waiter last week and speak English very fine.

Hello~~ I saw u last week and also few month ago and last year too. ( don't act u r new)

They wrote in Chinese which we might not understand but
We can check with the menu!!!!

If u order Chinese broccoli, be aware they might charge more!!!!!

Never heard expensive Chinese broccoli additional is $1.50.

Keep watch out the check whether they make overprice.

Except this,the food taste good.
author: Winny L.

description: We were in the area during lunch time on a Sunday, and found this restaurant randomly while walking around. Since we were hungry and the Yelp reviews for this place seem reasonable, we decided to give it a shot. We were able to get a table for two and were given the menu right away. Upon first examining the menu, we were pleasantly surprised by the larger variety of food options offer here. We we were also happy to see how affordable the lunch menu items were, with many meals offered at $6 or less. We ordered two lunch rice platters and the dry chicken wing, all were quite good. The portions were generous and the flavors were nice. The only downside was that the service was slow-they seemed to be understaffed at that time because we waited quite a while before the waiter came to take our order, and he was obviously busy taking care of all the other tables. Overall, a nice affordable place to get some good Chinese food for lunch, especially if you're not in a rush.
author: Sarah W.

description:
Low expectations for this Cantonese restaurant in Richmond district. Place has been here for a while, and ownership has changed many times over the years. Here's the rundown:

Beef chow fun: No wok flavor. Texturally, too thick. Average.

Crispy roasted chicken: Too salty. Texturally, dry and old. Below average.

Stir Fried green beans: Too salty as well. OK texture.

Though the restaurant is old and dingy on the inside, all of the tables were occupied by large parties (8+). 

At least they didn't try to hustle us like Hong Kong Lounge.
author: Jay C.

description:
Not bad for my neighborhood traditional chinese restaurant.  the best dish was the smooth tofu on top of egg white with shrimp pieces and green peas.  

friendly staff.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Exploring rules ! This place was really good. I dont know about it being *Superior* but I would eat there again. We shared the Pot Stickers which were tasty and came with some red vinaigrette, the combination fried rice which was a huge portion and really delicious. I ordered Kung Pao beef and it was also really good. It had one of those red chili peppers and holy crap was it potent.. lots of veggies and beef. The misses had a clay pot with chicken , eggplant and salted fish and she was in heaven. If youre in the neighborhood and trying to decide where to go, there are a few places to try.. try this one first ! 

PS - the service was fine,  in case youre wondering.. he took the order did his job and kept refilling my cup with water because of that damn red pepper that just felt like something blew up in my mouth ..

PSS - the prices I felt were reasonable. the problem is it takes a lot of Chinese food to fill me up so we order a lot !
author: David S.

description:
This is the spot that my family and I head to for family dinners on Sundays. The people that eat here have been coming for years, very family friendly. It's really an understated restaurant and really worth a try. 

They have a varied menu, but it's a must to get fresh seafood. All the specials are written in chinese, but most likely you'll see it on a neighboring table; so just point and ask. The free salad that they offer is pretty generic but I love the dressing. Always ask what fresh seafood they have, I really recommend the geoduck and fresh live shrimp if they have it. The portions are large but can be easily saved for the next days lunch. 

The service is also good, although you can tell they are much more comfortable speaking in chinese. Food comes out fast and hot, and they'll come around to replace dirty plates so you can resume eating. 

I do have to say, the bathroom is less than satisfactory; so just hold it. 

In conclusion, a great place to get authentic Chinese food in the city.
author: Ingrid H.

description:
2.5 stars

I'd like to keep an open mind about the place but our first experience of the food here was not very exciting even though the service was decent.  

We ordered the $128 family dinner plus a couple of ala carte dishes for 9 of us, we had a lot of food (crab, chicken, quail, fish, prawns, etc) and a lot of left overs.... the food was not terrible but not very tasty. To be fair, we saw many yummy looking dishes on other tables, perhaps we made a mistake of ordering preset menu.

We may come back but will definitely order from the ala carte menu.
author: Julie W.

description: Food is good, service is good. Always busy on the weekends. One of my favs is the dry fried chicken wings. It's not spicy compared to other ones I've tried. Their dried scallop egg white fried rice is da bomb. We get it every time. Price is very reasonable. Definitely recommend this place. I have not visited the bathroom so can't judge. Overall a great place.
author: Anna J.

description: They had to increase their menu price, because they aren't as busy as a few years ago.  Used to go there regularly but not anymore.  Food is average and nothing spectacular.  The owner is very friendly and helpful.
author: Roland F.

description:
I rolled in here with about thirty people deep and enjoyed a delicious banquet style Cantonese dinner celebrating a family member's birthday in the private room to the left.  This place is pretty good for their friendly, attentive service and their non-greasy Chinese food- two things which typically lack in many Chinese restaurants in addition to nice decor which measured up to okay but better than most.

I will go on about the great service first.  Our empty plates were bussed almost immediately.  If our plates were full of discards, the waiters exchanged them with clean plates.  The tea pots stayed full.  The servers walked around with warm smiles and catered to our requests solicitously.

Our dinner consisted of several dishes which were tasty, far from greasy and mostly devoured down to a clean plate.  (fried crab, honey walnut prawns, shrimp, pork fried rice, crab soup, squab, chicken...etc)  The red bean soup that came at the end, however, was an epic fail.  It was't red and possessed more of a light brown color to it.  Yes, it tasted awful.  Rarely anyone digs sweet red bean soup at these places anyways.  

The decor in this place was acceptable.  There was an idle attempt in the main dining room with uniform artwork in black frames lining the far wall but for the most part, there is no sense of true aesthetics taken into consideration.  The private room we were in had a tiny red and gold sign written in Chinese slightly larger than a bumper sticker at the top of the otherwise white wall (odd placement), and everyone sat under a cheap acoustical tiled ceiling with what appeared to be random placement of recessed lighting.  The cheesy white place mats over the white table cloths made me wonder.  It's not as if they prevent any sort of mess on the white table cloths- just more mess and more waste.  Nevertheless, the lighting in this place is a bit dimmer than the annoying bright fluorescent lights that seem to plague most of these Richmond/Sunset Chinese restaurants.

If they gave this place more ambiance, I might give it a four star, but my school cafeteria offers better aesthetics.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: This place is SO BOMB! we walked in 5 minutes before they closed (yah I know, our bad) and they were so nice to seat us! We got the fried rice, potstickers, and honey walnut shrimp and each dish was cooked perfectly and delicious. We scarfed it all down. Great service, awesome food, good prices- will definitely be back!
author: Cher B.

description: My family has been going here for years and the service has always been been very good when we go. It is not a fancy Chinese restaurant but they serve pretty authentic food. The prices are reasonable and we have always been pretty satisfied. We would go back.
author: Nina C.

description:
We popped in on a Wednesday night around 8 pm.  Several tables occupied by other diners, but we got a table for the six of us. We went with the prefixed menu aka wo choy.   4-6 people.  We also a couple of additional dishes.

Pros - food came quickly.  Soup was good as was the deep fried flounder.

Cons - portion size skimpy.  Especially the honey glazed walnut shrimp dish.  Lucky if there were a dozen on the plate.  Chinese mustard greens over cooked.

Overall good food.
author: Shirley N.

description:
This place is big on Chinese style family dinners, and for that it's decent. I've eaten there once a year for many years, but ...

If I was eating just for two and in the neighborhood - I'd pick Kim Son or Jade Garden.
author: A D.

description:
There are three things that separate Superior Palace from other traditional Chinese restaurants in the area. 

First is speed. I call to order take out and am told my food will be ready in 15 minutes. That is almost not even enough time to get into my car and pick it up. But you have to love that they will have your food ready ASAP.

Second is the focus on seafood. If you are looking for Chinese food with an emphasis on seafood then look no further. 

Finally the price is exceptional. By exceptional I mean that every dish you order will be a dollar or two cheap than the equivalent else where but you are not getting less food.

The only reason they lose a star is because of the lack of delivery service. I live close enough that it is not a huge deal but it would still be a nice option.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I was skeptical because of the hokey name, but this eponymous restaurant lives up to it.

If you like actual Chinese food (as opposed to the Americanized wok fried  permutations of salt, soy sauce, sour, sweet, grease, corn starch meat and soggy vegetable dishes so common in many so-called Chinese restaurants), this is the place for you.

My favorite authentic home style dishes from this restaurant include:

*Sliced Pork with Taro - succulent, tender fatty strips of pork with sweet taro slices
*Steamed Pork Cake with Salt Fish- pungent to those unaccustomed to salt fish dishes, but recommended for those who love it!
*Peking Duck - Although ubiquitous, Superior Palace did a particularly good job preparing this classic with crispy skin and moist meat

The service was quite adequate as well. Not entirely eager to please, but competent, polite and prompt. 

Among many visits to this restaurant was a banquet for my father's birthday with ten guests. Succinctly put, good time was had by all, and everyone left happy and full.
author: Stuart Y.

description: FRAUD ALERT! We had a decent family dinner here last week. I paid for the meal including tip on my debit card. Last night I checked my account and noticed that an additional $10.00 on top of the $6.00 that I had tipped was added to the total! Be very careful when tipping by card! Needless to say, we are never coming back here agin.
author: Sirin T.

description: Diverse menu, but rather than serve me my order they gave me an Americanized alternative instead.  I have a problem with that. There is no benefit to having a diverse menu, if they refuse to serve it to American customers.
author: Joseph B.

description: I have enjoyed the food at this place up until today. It was mediocre at best today, and then they decided for the first time not to take my credit card because of a minimum amount rule that they haven't brought to my attention the four other times I went there. I saw the sign when I looked for it, hidden behind their desk that you don't go up to to pay your bill. Hit or miss, here. They also really only pay attention to the big parties. Be prepared to be relatively ignored if you are only one or two people.
author: Chris S.

description:
We stumbled onto this place because I totally messed up by not carefully reading that another restaurant I wanted to take my friends to a block away was closed on Tuesdays. Apparently there are a few restaurants along Balboa Ave. closed on Tuesdays.   According to my trusty Yelp App, this place would be a good back-up plan.

THE BAD NEWS
Bright fluorescent lights, semi-sticky lazy susan, disheveled front counter with magazines strewn around it, and only one other group of Asians quickly eating their meal in the background gave us pause to think that we might have chosen unwisely.  However, we were too tired, hungry, and annoyed at the light rain outside to remove ourselves. 

THE GOOD NEWS
I'm glad we stayed.  The folks were nice and accommodated a few necessities of ours. But most importantly, the food was good - enough so, that I'll keep them in mind next time I'm in the area.  What I liked most about this place was the simplicity of the food - seasoned just right and NO worn-down fishy taste that often accompanies places that specialize in seafood.

WHAT WE ORDERED
Fried Flounder - Perfectly fried, tender flesh, very crispy skin, and light soy sauce and green onion broth was a perfect accompaniment, allowing the delicate flavors of the flounder to show itself. If you've never had flounder before, get it!  At $10.95 for a whole fish, it's quite a value.

Spicy Mandarin Beef - Simple presentation with sauteed julienne green peppers and onions with tender beef. The beef glaze with a nice kick from the freshly cracked black pepper swimming it was pretty tasty - enough so that we harnessed whatever sauce was leftover on the skillet it was presented in and ate it with rice.

Minced Beef Soup -Simple tasty, thick clear broth soup, with tender egg whites. Nothing to dance a jig over,  but comfort food soup.

Chinese Broccoli with Oyster Sauce - Can't go wrong here.  A good green and fresh accompaniment to the other dishes.

Snow Pea Shoots - This was the favorite green dish of the night.  Simple, but it was full of flavor and offer a really tender texture. 

Two Salt and Pepper Quails - a very unusual offering, two of my friends had to try it.  They were pleased.  They both agreed the quail flesh proved more flavor than chicken.  They liked how crispy it was and how it was served with ample fried garlic, jalapenos, and red peppers.

BBQ Pork Chow Mein Hong Kong Style - Great smoky flavor, thin and crispy vermicelli egg noodles.  One of the better versions of this dish.

Complimentary warm tapioca dessert with diced taro.  Score!
author: Paolo M.

description:
I tried here couple times since I moved to this street. Food is pretty good and price is always reasonable. 
Usually I get beef chow-fun. I still think it should have more veggies, eat healthy people :)) .
I will give better star if I dont have to call someone for help over and over. I stand in front of them saying hello for like 5 times but they pretend not to here me. I guess they are kitchen people who dont speak english. I hope the ownet will tell them to say wait wait or at least using body language instead of just ignoring.
author: George A.

description:
Interesting cantonese seafood place. The insides look a bit shabby, but then, it's a Chinese place right? To set things right....seafood places in Hong Kong are either right by the sea (you eat outside and it's more run down), or it's some nice banquet place that can be somewhat presentable. I'm not sure how people can have wedding banquets in this place, but...alright.

Anyway. We ordered a couple dishes, namely the salt and pepper prawns, the chinese broccoli with oyster sauce, the taro crispy duck, and the e-fu noodles with crab meat. Let me go over them one by one.

Salt and pepper prawns: Shell's on, so prepare to get your hands dirty. The seasoning is just right, and the prawns are quite fresh. I liked it.

Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce: the veggies were cooked right, but the oyster sauce was...what brand did they use again? Why does it taste funny?

Taro crispy duck: Crowd pleaser dish, also very filling because of the taro in it. It was good but they didn't distribute or chop the duck up enough that you have to hunt for the duck under the yummy taro-ness. Wish they would've done it right so each piece of taro gets some duck because both the duck and the taro tasted great.

E-fu noodles with crab meat: Very disappointing. The crab meat is real crab meat, but other then that, nothing surprising with this dish and I can whip up a better version at home myself.

Overall, it's as good as any other Cantonese restaurants, there are some good stuff I had, and some not-so-good stuff. If I ever come here again, I'd bring a huge group so I can try more of their dishes to see how the overall quality is, but so far, not very impressed.
author: Alice C.

description: I've came here with a few friends.  One of my friends found a long white strand of hair in his rice plate.   Mongolian Beef over Rice.  He didn't find the hair sitting on his plate, but felt something weird in his mouth.  So he pulled it out of his mouth and felt it travel out of he throat.  It was a long strand of white hair with pieces of rice stuck to it.  Now, none of us had long white hair.  Just a few guys with short black hair.  So it wasn't any of our hair.  My friend didn't eat the rest of his rice dish.  When the waiter came with the check, we showed the long white hair to him.  My other friend said "look, you guys are adding ingredients to the food!".  No response from the waiter.  Only a smile.  Took our money and gave us change.  That's the last time any of us are eating here.
author: Jack L.

description:
Grandparents and Parents conspired to have my traditional chinese banquet here...

lots of our friends are not familiar with these things and stuffed themselves silly on the first three dishes and rendered them unable to enjoy the garlic fried crab, walnut shrimp, squab, garlic chicken, ginger sea bass, mixed fried rice, shrimp and broccoli, etc etc etc

nine courses in all. Pretty good sharkfin soup, fried rice, squab & sea bass, everything else was aok to me. My hubby LOVED the walnut shrimp and the pastor's wife coulda polished off the crab on her own.

i would def come here again just for the sea bass!
author: Chriss L.

description:
Ok, this place just earned another 1/2 star so 3.5 stars for this place! 

Went here last night with my bf and his family and the food just got better. 
Maybe it was the selection of food we got? or the food tasted extra fresh. 
Deep Fried Crab = fresh
Deep Fried Fish = fresh 
Honey Walnut Shrimp = fresh fresh fresh 
Calms = freshest of em all! 

okay, basically all the seafood stuff was really fresh. I am not a big fan of seafood, but the food we ordered yesterday was all delicious! The Shanghai Noodles are really good too! I love how the egg noodle is so thick and fat. 

Ok, that's my update. That's it for now.
author: Katrina T.

description:
3.5 stars but it'll round up because the service is great and I really think they can improve to make it four star worthy. 

Recently I can here for a quick dinner with the bf. We had the minced beef soup, 1 geoduck (1 giant clam/2 pieces), mustard greens in garlic sauce, and salt and pepper cod fillet.

Minced beef soup: Wasn't mind blowing, but it was warm and comforting. Bf's tummy was a little unsettling, but this made him feel so much better after a warm bowl of soup. Thick pieces of tender egg whites and a great broth.

Geoduck: I really enjoyed this. The clam was sauteed and served in the shell on a bed of thin rice noddles in a light soy broth. Garnished with some slice scallions. yum!

Mustard greens: Pieces were tender and a nice green color. However, it was a bit too oily and could have used a little more garlic.

Salt and pepper fish fillet: nice and crispy, but could have also used a little more of the "salty" aspect.

Overall: this place could use a face lift to the ambiance and decor, but the food was good and the prices were fair. Service was attentive and friendly. Would I go back? Definitely.
author: Jenna H.

description: Been here a few times for the multi-course meals.  Actually came here on Xmas day (be there early!).  We say in the side room, which helped with the noise.  No real complaints about service or food quality.  We had the $88 meal with an extra order of beef chow fun.  It seemed like most of the dishes were on the small side.  We had 7 of us and after each took a piece of chicken, there were only a few pieces left.  Seems like that was true for virtually every dish.  Just some small portioning.  Food taste was fine though.
author: Glenn L.

description: MAN!!! can you say " WORST PLACE EVER". Came here on behalf of Yelp was I wrong! Came here on Christmas Day with the Family and order the banquet style menu. When the food came out and we all taste it, Can you just say YUCK! I Think we will make KL Restaurant on Balboa and 47th Ave our place now! My Niece told me that even China First on Clement and 4th Ave taste better and that's not saying much for them either!  The check came and it was over $200.00! It should have been $30.00 for the 10 people banquet!! I would not  recommend this place to my worst enemy!! DON'T GO TO THIS PLACE!!! DON'T GET RIPPED OFF!!
author: D D.

description: I come here all the time for family dinners and the food here has always been mediocre. Compared to other Chinese restaurants, this place is cheap. The food lacks flavor. When I ate here I had an Asian fruit salad drenched in mayo. I also had some lobster noodles that weren't fresh and smelled musty. We had to ask the waiter to take it back.  Everything else tastes decent. There's nothing special about the place. For big groups, they do have a lot of seating
author: Kristy L.

description:
01.29.11

I don't know why the waiter keeps calling my mom "cousin", I'm fairly certain that we're not related.

Doesn't matter, we got a free appetizer, veggie dish and dessert anyhow.

This place was packed on Saturday at 7:00.  After a 20 minute wait we were finally seated.  The fam got to ordering quickly.  The kitchen was backed up quite a bit, so there was some sit and wait time between courses.

Most of the dishes were fresh and nicely prepared.  Go for the drunken clams and the squab!
author: Jenny L.

description:
I haven't been here for over 20 years and I'm sure it's under different management. We came after a funeral today and I had to write this review since most of the ones I've written lately are all negative. I seldom give 4 stars but this one deserved it.

5 stars
Jai: this is a vegetarian dish and was my favorite. 
Chinese broccoli with beef: omg, can you spell tender? the broccoli was flawless, every piece young and tender.
Braised Bean Cake with baby bok chou: cooked to perfection, veggies were young & tender

4 stars
Sauteed prawns, calamari, and fish with greens: another dish done right
Spicy Salt & Pepper Flounder Fish Fillet: the batter was delicate, fish was NOT overcooked, flavor was devine

3 stars
pea sprouts with garlic: I heard this was good but I don't eat pea sprouts

2 stars
steam chicken: a bit overcooked and bland which brought the overall rating down
roast pork: this was not prepared by the restaurant, the skin was harder than it was crispy but forgiven since it was ordered out

I will come back for dinner with my family and update :o)
author: May G.

description:
OK, So, the terms "Excellent Attentive Service" and "Ethnic Chinese Dining" really do not marry well together.  That said, Superior Palace offers good/very good food with brisk, indifferent, and, at times, chaotic service. 

During peak times, the noise level in here can become deafening, dishes are delivered to wrong tables,  and the wait for a table can be long. In spite of that, we really feel the seafood here is better quality, has greater variety,  and costs less than Mayflower Seafood located not far away. 

The trick is to come here during the "off" times (before 12 noon, after 1:30 PM, before 6:00 PM, and after 8:30 PM).  The best bets at Superior Palace are the fresh fish (the holding tanks really do need to be cleaned more often), crab, prawns, clams, yummy duck (try the one in bbq sauce), stir fried Chinese greens, and ooodles of noodles!
author: Richard T.

description:
I miss Hong Kong. This place reminds me of a very Hong Kong/Cantonese style, big family dinner restaurant. I love the atmosphere. It's hectic and busy. 

The food is delicious. Their seafood is excellent and their chicken is very yummy.  Everything on their menu is good - I have no complaints.

The service is pretty good. They take our plates away about 3 times during the meal and they are very attentive. 

I love this place!
author: Vanessa W.

description:
These guys were great!
We reserved 4 banquet tables and ordered the basic banquet menu,
plus asked them for 3 additional veggie dishes to be served first,
and every dish was good to superior.  
All 40 guests were happy with the accommodations and 
quality and quantity of the dozen+ dishes.
When we first went to reserve the tables, the head waiter suggested
several alternates to the set menu and they turned out well.

We will definitely return for any large gathering as well as 
small family get-togethers whenever we want a traditional
Cantonese menu.  Overall, very good menu at a fair price.
You don't have to go downtown to get good eats.

Most suprizing was that everyone in our party found parking within
a couple of blocks for our Friday 7pm gathering.
author: Lawrence L.

description:
Had my wedding rehearsal dinner there. Super accommodating with seating and menu.

Also, lunch specials are reasonably priced and filling.
author: David K.

description:
3.5 stars overall.

Every restaurant has good dishes and some not so good dishes (well, most places anyway unless they are just horrible).  Anyway, I absolutely love the salt and pepper eggplant and salt and pepper chicken wings at Superior Palace.  Their eggplant is freakin' amazing!...fried to a golden crisp on the outside with the right amount of seasoning...yum, yum, yum!  The same is true for their chicken wings and these dishes deserve 5 stars on their own.

Unfortunately, the quality and taste of their other dishes are not always consistent.  Their noodle dishes can be bland at time and entrees alternate between being salty and bland depending on what you order =/

Service is just like any other Chinese place where you have to flag down a waiter if you need something.
author: Katelynn L.

description: Above average food, great service, and extremely clean restrooms for a Chinese restaurant.
author: Kevin L.

description:
A cleaner but smaller plated version of Best Panda.  We've gone here since they opened last year.  Food is good.  Place is always crowded on the weekends so reservations for large parties are a must.  Tables are big so the dining room can be cramped.  Definitely try their Garlic Chicken.  It's the best!

I'm giving it 3 stars instead of 4 because lately they've been trying to gouge you on the bill.  For instance, rice is 60 per person.  We had 2 infants in our party (obviously they can't eat!) but when the bill came, they charged the infants for rice money.  Obviously we made a huge stink about that!  Definitely not cool in my book.  I'd prefer you raise the menu prices rather than being sneaky about it (to add insult to injury, we're regulars too!).  Word of advice, review the bill before paying.
author: Wendy H.

description:
While waiting for a feature at the Balboa Theater, we happened to try the Superior Palace Seafood Restaurant. The place was filled with large parties, and we were seated quickly and waited on promptly.
Great place to go with large parties or family and eat well reasonably. 
The mixed vegetables were super fresh and cooked to perfection.
We also had sizzling prawns and scallops that were brought out with a napkin cover to eliminate the sizzling splatter. Wish there was an authentic Chinese restaurant like this in Walnut Creek. The price for enough food and even have some to take home was less than $40 including tax. We will be back.
author: George H.

description:
Have been passed by so many times before and decided to give it a try in a weekend afternoon. Since we have only 2 adults and 2 small kids, we decided to order a chicken corn soup, yang zhou fried rice and family style fried rice noodles. The dishes were okay not impressively delicious. However later on, I realized that they possibly did not put MSG because I did not feel thirsty and that was why the food seem a bit bland in taste. To me, I prefer no MSG and I don't like food too salty.

The family style fried rice noodles was tasty, especially the next day when I ate the leftover. There were cuttle fishes, scallops, shrimps in it and I have not tried a dish like it before. My family possibly would go back for dinner another time.
author: Roserrele W.

description:
3.5
I dont know how expensive this place is so this is just a review about the food. I had the yellow feathered chicken, fried fish, a vegetable with shrimp stir fry, bok choy with mushrooms, roasted pork, and the red bean tapioca dessert. I would say this is a typical chinese restaurant but with nothing to exceptional to round up to a 4. The main thing I would tip my hat off to for this place is their freshness. The food tasted as if it was prepared from ingredients not sitting around but the flavor was not anything special. SInce this is a little further away from other chinese restaurants, Id only go here if other family members were attending. Overall its a decent chinese restaurant but nothing too amazing to recommend over another restaurant.
author: Robert Y.

description:
We come here for a lot of family dinners.

The food's not bad. Pretty flavorful. Food was spicy when it's supposed to be. I really liked the Salt and Pepper Spareribs and the Clam in Black Bean Sauce. We also had beef stew, a vegetable dish, and a lettuce wrap appetizer. 

Dinner for 5 was around $60. 

Service is usually attentive, but like other places, once it's packed, be prepared to have to state your requests twice. They're also pretty friendly. They're nice to kids, even when they're running around.
author: Florence S.

description:
dinner on a rainy night.

great food.  chicken watercress soup ( really good ), clams with basil (outstanding), broccolli beef - very good, and steam fish. ( was the weakest dish of the night).  

worth coming back
author: Bill L.

description:
I was pretty blown away with the wor won ton soup.  The soup base tasted clean and good, it had fresh fish, calamari, bbq pork, shrimp, and vegetables.  For six dollars..... it is a bargain.  You can probably get full by just eating this by itself.  Everything else is pretty plain jane but decent.  The salt and pepper ribs, the garlic and vegetables and their fatty pork with preserved veggies were good.  

Really can't say too much about this place.  It's your typical Chinese restaurant in the Richmond district.  

31 dollars for the whole meal and will probably have leftovers for the next two days.  It's raining so it should come in handy this week.
author: jason g.

description:
I had some time to kill while waiting for the a movie to start at the Balboa Theater, so i did a quick Yelp search on my Phone and found this place. I just had a quick meal here, but it seemed as if this was a great place to get a few friends together and chow down for hours with conversation and drinks.

my only complaint was that the service seemed to overlook me a little, this is probabally because I was here alone, but that shouldn't be an excuse.

The food was probabally the best quality Chinese I have had in the city for that price range.
author: Josh B.

description:
Update for Tuesday, 13-April-2009 at 8:00 PM

New decorations: Some great paintings (or watercolors?) on the wall of Chinese landscapes.  They actually have a book of the artist's work, that I had seen on a previous visit.

Service:  fast, friendly, and courteous, as always.

Drinks:  hot tea, only because we'd be going out for beers afterwards

Food: Two plates + fried rice:
1. Cod filets in black bean sauce (excellent.  they also offer two other prep styles in case you don't like black bean sauce)
2. Salt and pepper pork ribs (also excellent.  served hot out of the fryer, topped with sliced peppers, salt, and small bits of garlic)
3. Some kind of combination fried rice with chopped bits of Chinese sausage and dried shrimp and using sticky rice (excellent.  i normally order plain steamed white rice, but this was so good i'll consider ordering it again)

We had a nice dessert (a bowl each of something sweet and tasty) and some sliced oranges.

Price: incredibly reasonable.

Outer Richmond places have better leases and spend almost zero dollars on advertising.

If a place has been around as long as Superior Palace has, and is filled almost every night with hungry locals, then they must be doing something right.
author: Justin C.

description: Decided to go exotic tonight.  Chinese it is! Not much I can say except it was very good.  Try the wong-ton soup. Not too salty perfect.  Forks available u need only ask!
author: William H.

description:
Hiked up here with some friends in the bay to breakers aftermath.  Pretty empty except for a couple of families scattered about.  And the two wasted guys out cold and laid out on a bed of chairs.  Above them was table full of untouched food and the beers they ordered when they arrived.  Talk about a sudden collapse.... 

To the food.  A better name for this place would be "Not So Superior Palace."  Just another mediocre Chinese restaurant.  They brought out some complimentary soup to start out with, though they shouldn't have even bothered.  It was essentially a bland broth with few carrots and bits of meet floating about.  An uninspiring way to begin the meal.  Here's the rest of our meal:  

Egg rolls - standard.  Nothing to write home about.  
Walnut prawns - pretty good, probably my favorite item.  But i've rarely been disappointed by walnut prawns.
Whole cod - Good, but not worth the $20 price tag.  The fish in the tank didn't look like they were moving much.
Pork fried rice - bland.  A letdown after experiencing Abacus' pork fried rice.
Kung Pao Chicken - also bland.  Tragically lacking in spice. 

Service was bare-bones.  I had to harrass to waiter to get water & refills. 

I'd give this place a few more chances if I lived in the neighborhood, especially since other than the whole fish everything was dirt cheap.  But I don't see myself coming back.              

2.5 STARS
author: Leon R.

description: One of the few places that has the chinese dish jiew yiem gnow jai gwut, or salt and pepper beef ribs.. tis my all time favorite dish.. and no one ever makes it anywhere anymore. The beef ribs are really good, very tasty, and tender. One negative thing is that they give you hella little, and for $10.40, one can get two dishes.. but sometimes u just gotta have what u gotta have. good restaurant, i would recommend.
author: simon k.

description:
Pretty much just another Cantonese restaurant in a sea of many, many more here in the Bay Area. My family and I like to come here a lot. And it sure as hell isn't for the decor (which is . . . umm, I'm still looking for it). The ambiance of this restaurant sucks - the ceilings are high and, no offense - I'm Chinese too, Cantonese people are loud, yo. Not a date place or someplace for a nice, intimate conversation - but what can you expect? This is a REAL Chinese restaurant! No gimmicks, no novelty bullshit, it's just really decent food.

Don't order the pre-set banquet meals - they're a little too pricey and overhyped, in my opinion.  Instead, come here and order yourself off the menu.  All the tofu claypots (my favorite is the salty fish and chicken - try that in the fried rice variety too, if you're salty fish fan, it's BOMB!) are yummy with a plain bowl of rice - tasty and the best kind of comfort food. The seafood is always fresh and tasty. The dry fried string beans always come piping hot, fresh and is fantastically garlicky and flavorful - same goes for their sauteed beef that comes on a hot plate. My absolute favorite is the garlic roasted (fried? Don't tell me, I really am better off not knowing) chicken! It's tender, juicy, the skin is crispy - falls right off, and there's crispy garlic bits baked into and generously scattered all over the whole thing.

It does suck to get a seat sometimes, though, and sometimes they'll get creative and push small tables together (while possibly breaking some kind of safety hazard . . . but, dude, my one track mind reads: food). So, hey, if you're a real Chinese (or want to feel like one), stuff like this and crowds (UMM check out Chinatown, por favor) shouldn't be a thing to you, G.
author: Betty W.

description:
If you're out near ocean, or maybe you're going to see a movie across the street, and in the mood for some Chinese, and more specifically seafood Chinese, then you have to swing by here.

An assortment of authentic dishes, live fish/lobster which turn into your meal and a variety of other meats  ( try the Lemon Chicken and the Salt & Pepper Squid )  are all delicious even if they are served by not so friendly staff.

Get a few more items to go if you won't be back in the neighborhood for a while as it's pretty far from town.
author: Mike J.

description:
I was with my Olympic archery coach and we were walking around Balboa. We popped into SP to check it out and ended up belly full. the reasonable prices and quality of seafood is great. 

We ordered clams w/ black bean sauce, prawns w/ lobster sauce, steamed doh-miu which is like a chinese spinach with oyster sauce and white rice. Not only was it delicious but they gave us alot!

A must eat place if you're having friends or family over.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
it has been over 6 years since the last time i set foot in superior palace. immediately, i noticed that the dining room had received a facelift...tasteful artwork on the walls, new carpeting, new paint...the room just seemed to be much cleaner. we even noticed that the jar of hot sauce on the lazy susan was free of the dried up goop you usually see at chinese restaurants. 

between 4 people we had:

claypot oxtails - fall off the bone tender
spicy pork intestines - w/jalapenos and dried shrimp...sublime
stir fried frog's legs - served w/snow peas and lotus petals
stir fried watercress - fresh, cooked perfectly
fried little fish - no idea what type of fish but i can eat this everyday 

affordable, authentic cantonese food served by friendly folks. btw, the hot sauce is ridiculously good!
author: Rob D.

description:
You know it felt weird coming to this vicinity for Chinese food and not going to Kam's... but it's time to move on. I needed to expand my horizons in this genre, so after my second visit, here's my scoop.

The service here is fast and friendly. Before you can notice... bang... the water glasses are filled and the tea pot is freshened.Don't worry, buddy... you're gonna get the full percentage tip! 

The Hung-Tao yee wonton soup is very good, especially the egg flower broth. The beef and mustard greens is outstanding, and the salt/pepper spareribs are very tender. We also had the cod fillets in Blk Bean sauce. Excellent. Don't get the steamed pork cake with salted fish... every other place that serves this dish does it better. Other than that this place is pretty solid. Portions are fairly generous too.

Not very old school (60's Chinatown... I'm still searching), but if some one suggests to go here, don't hesitate. Did I say the prices are very reasonable? That's another big plus. So, if you landed on the "Chance" space...

Do not pass GO... Do Not Collect $200... Go Directly to Superior Palace!
author: Rick V.

description:
Dependable and tasty Chinese food at reasonable prices. Tucked away in the far corners of the Richmond district, Superior Palace is a no-frills Chinese restaurant that serves up tasty and fresh classics with an emphasis on seafood. The food is above average and pretty much what you would expect from a decent Chinese restaurant. The crab was especially delicious and nothing like the crap that was served for 2+ times the price at HKFL (review forthcoming). The prices are about average, too, for no-frills Chinese. What I liked, however, is how clean the restaurant looked. 

Sure, it's no-frills in a "let's stick a random painting of Chinese flowers on the wall and call it art while covering the entire rest of the wall with scribbled menu specialties written entirely in Chinese" way. However, it's a large space that has clean white walls, and, unlike other, more sketchy Chinese food places, the floors never seem to be scattered with those random food pieces/dropped chopsticks/dropped and/or soiled napkins that litter the floors in other no-frills joints.

Their bathrooms are also surprisingly, shockingly clean. Taking into account the locale, you really do not know what to expect when entering into the hallowed halls labeled "Women" (or "Men," I assume, but not having visited that one, I can't really vouch for that half). Anyway, we're not talking the Park Hyatt or anything, but it's fully stocked with TP, actual honest-to-goodness pump soap, and paper towels. Yippee!

All in all, if I have to go for Chinese (which I oftentimes do considering my dad's limited adventurousness in all things epicurean), this place is A-okay in my books. And, let's be honest, if my grandma really likes this place, they can't be too far off in their ties to the motherland.
author: Audrey J.

description: To start off, I actually been here several times years back and it was a decent place to pick up some getaway food, the price was alright. It's eatable alright. Came around on saturday night and it was 9:50pm, I went to their place and before going in, checked the operation hour before heading in, it says to close at 10:00pm. So i thought i was in luck, upon entering there was a group of people that left the restaurant and the lady that follows after that group dashed to the door and I thought she was going to hold the door for me. Guess what? When I barely had the door handle on my finger tips, she quickly smashed the door close and stood there staring at me while she was locking the door. Literally stood there and stared at me. What gives?
author: Joe W.

description:
I'm not the greatest fan of Chinese food, but this place wasn't bad at all! We had over a dozen dishes definitely. About 4 of them stood out and was really delicious. My usual, blackbean sauce clams? The battered/friend pork chops were really good. I usually don't eat more than a piece if any, because so much of it is fried with the fatty part instead of the lean part. But this one was good.. I also really liked the melon soup we had (geet gwa). And finally, I ate something I usually wouldn't go for, but it was just so good! It was some kind of beef brisket (but not really) boiling pot thing. And finally, their dessert was different from most other Chinese place's and pretty good too. 

But of course, it was a semi-family reunion where everybody wanted to take hella pictures. Thank goodness we were the only ones in that side of the restaurant, otherwise it would've been even more embarrassing! But the waiters were being really nice about it =)

p.s. we got 2 free dishes. I don't know if they were being nice or cause someone knew someone.
author: Elaine H.

description:
The food here is decent. I'm not really a big fan of this place since I feel that almost every HK style restaurant on Balboa only deserve a 3 star at most. Food here has nothing special, atmosphere in here feels kinda weird. I feel kind of gloomy everytime i walk in, because it has that  traditional chinese setting.  

Bottom line : If you want a simple chinese dinner, this place is a really nice place to go. The food here is reasonable from it's quality to it's price.
author: William C.

description:
Love this place. 

They are one of the few people that have yee wonton soup. Delicious. It's fried wonton in a egg drop/rice soup. Really good, you have to try it. They also have a shrimp and egg chow fun that is worth trying. 

Other then that, they have your basic Chinese food...sweet and sour...etc...as well as salty fish and pork cake (my favee) and tofu clay pots. Great for huge families. In fact, my family is going there to celebrate Chinese New Years' tomorrow.
author: Alison N.

description:
Hit and miss.  They have Hit more than miss though so I will review them based on their hits.  The waiter here had previously worked for 8 Immortals on Taraval and this place is probably the 8 Immortals of the Richmond.  And since I have always liked 8 Immortals, I guess I like this place too.  

Once, we ordered take out here for Chinese New Years though and it was very average.  But they were really, really busy that night so maybe you try to come here when they are not so so busy.  

Take a peak inside, if they are busy as hell, try something else in the neighborhood.  If they look like they are not so busy, go check it out.....
author: Mark W.

description: Superior Palace Restaurant, at Balboa Street was a popular Chinese Restaurant to eat back in my high school days... Its been such a very long long time that, I have not gone back to Superior Palace since gradulatiing from George Washington High School. I just wonder if the food still taste the same and also the prices on the Superior Palace menu if it gone up or not . I always had a good time eating here for lunch or dinner!!!
author: William B.

description:
Good local restaurant for those living in the Richmond.  Might even be worth the trip from beyond.  Food is good, prices are about what'd you expect for a normal chinese restaurant.

Nothing spectacular, but definitely a very dependable and sure choice for a good chinese meal.

Great service, not like chinatown.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
This place has got great food and very reasonable prices... in fact, the only thing keeping them from 5 stars in my book is the fact that, for some reason, when I go in there alone, they treat me like a goddess.... but when I go in with my significant other, the employees act like we don't exist.

Hmm.

On the positive side, I've never had a dish here I didn't like... the sweet and sour chicken is fabulous, and so are the veggie spring rolls.... The walnut prawns are killer, too. :)
author: Elle Q.

description: Really great place to dine with the entire family on a typical weekend. The service is extremely good and all the employees are professional in their line of work. I would recommend ordering all the deep fried foods because they do a really good job with it. Deep fried crab, deep fried pork ribs, deep fried fish, deep fried squid are all really good. Awesome place!
author: Harry B.

description: Located at the corner of 37th and Balboa, street parking only. I came here for a large banquet, over 100 people.  The banquet included salt & pepper crab, chinese chicken salad and ginger lobster.  While these dishes and overall the rest of the food was pretty good, it was not memorable or spectacular.  Not too bad for cooking such large quantities and I would come again, but there wasn't any one dish that would make me come back specifically to try again.  The service was good, very attentive, prompt and friendly.  Typical decor for a Chinese restaurant, again nothing special.  In a couple of months, I'll be saying, "what was the name of that place we went to on Balboa"?, which translates into A-OK, or a three star in Yelp.
author: Larry G.

description:
If you can get in before noon, this is an inexpensive place for lunch. At noon the place starts to fill with tons of painters and other people from the neighborhood. If you managed to get in before them, get your order in, then you're in a cheap, fast, and tasty lunch. If not...well relax.

They have "rice plates" hidden toward the back of the menu that offer a dish with a gigantic portion of rice. The plates are all about $4 and are more than you would ever need for lunch. I can take half back to work for tomorrow, technically lowering the bill to $2. 

My only qualm would be, some of the dishes seem to have more bones than meat. But I guess you get what you pay for.
author: Dixon T.

description:
I went there with my huge family on 1/1/2008 at night.

I know, I know.....it was very crowed when we came in since there were many people waiting.

luckily, we booked two tables in advance. however, we waited for about 50 mins to get our first dish---soup. (we booked @7pm, and got there @7pm, and got seated @7:15pm, and started to eat @ 8:04pm)

others seemed to have same situation.

there is not much space btwn each table. and I am a middle-size person, and feel so uncomfortable when eating

the family dinner and rice plate are very valuable, and overall it is clean, and waiter service is acceptable. 

one more thing, because of its low prices, u won't expect  very big plates; at the same time, u should have more varieties.

u will have some traditional food in the menu, which i feel glad to try.
author: Sue S.

description:
This is one of the many Chinese neighborhood restaurants that consistently serve well-proportioned and delicious dishes. Lunch time menu offers a wide variety and decent prices.  Their banquet dinners are also very good...you always find restaurants that seem to screw up the family banquet dinners but always serve better dishes for a smaller group. Go figure.

Their dim sum is good but still I would prefer KL Restaurant down by 46th/Balboa if given an option...but seafood here is always fresh and not overly salty or greasy.

I give props for cleanliness, because I have been to places that look great on the outside but completely trashed when it comes to the back area for the restrooms.
author: Pauline L.

description:
It's the place where Chinese food is really good and cheap[er] when compared to other places in SF and Bay Area. My family goes there so often, even the waiters and the owner knows us well - once you get to know them more, you can see that they're all cheerful people, especially the owner. Sometimes, they give us a free dish, and most of the time they don't charge us for the soup and the dessert (oranges AND tong sui!).

Note of caution though. It tends to be overcrowded on Fridays and weekend nights, so I would suggest that you go there around 8:30PM. When it gets overcrowded, it tends to be really noisy too - expect to talk really loud while eating dinner!
Also, this IS a Chinese restaurant, where they usually leave you alone unless your table needs to be cleared of empty dishes for even MORE food and whatnot - if you're looking for one of those high-end restaurants where they practically spoon-feed you the whole entire meal (ok, I'm exaggerating..), than yeeeah... 

And yes. Like everywhere else, this is a typical Chinese restaurant that serves typical Chinese family-style food. You will not find any "exotic foods" here.
author: Charmian W.

description: We had three things: 1) Fresh ginger crab, 2) String beans with ground pork and 3) Dumpling soup. The crab was fresh, but surprisingly bland. It needed salt/soy.  The soup had pretty decent dumplings, but the broth was almost flavorless. The strings beans were the only standout dish. They were very flavorful and had a nice spicy kick. The service was good, although the place was almost empty when we were there. Perhaps Cantonese style food is just a bit too bland for my tastes.
author: Yogi B.

description:
Several times I have passed by this restaurant and observed families dining. I decided to try this place. At 5: 30 PM, no one was there. I did not ask for menu. I knew what I wanted "Oyster & Roast Pork" clay pot. 
The waiter brought a lukewarm broth with a won ton and peanuts, plus tea. When my order was delivered, it looked fine. Where is the roast pork? I called waiter back & he points to small, slivers of what I believe is, BBQ pork. I told him, " this is not roast pork." He replied, "oh, it's pork. See" and proceeded to pick out the pieces with my chopstick until I had a small pile on the side plate. The cashier walked over & said nothing. They were indifferent and did not offer to correct my plate. They got my $8, but they will not get a return visit.
author: Sandy P.

description:
steamed half chicken and garlic mustard greens dishes
awesome dinner and leftover next day was even better!!
author: Win H.

description: Tried the fried calamari to go to try to find ben's next calamari spot,  it was pretty good, 8 bucks for a decent portion of fried calamari--no hot peppers like ben's old calamari spot. Will try more food next time!
author: Amy S.

description: I have been to Superior Palace many many many times but am just now getting into Yelp.  I have never been disappointed with the food and the service.  This is NOT a high end fussy fussy place, its a family eating out kind of place, they don't pull you chair out for you they point to a table and basically say "go there".  The get the food to you fast, bring you more napkins when you ask and other wise leave you to eat.  I have no issues with the place whatsoever, and those people work their butts off, so we appreciate all the effort.  I hope they make a million.  We have been to many of the Chinese places in the Richmond and as far as I am concerned they are Numero Uno.  And I read where someone didn't like the hostess.  Well, I wasn't there on that occasion, but if she was short with you, you probably did something to deserve it, she's a great gal, works like a mule.
author: Sarah H.

description:
At the urging of a friend, I decided to give this place a try.

They serve typical Canto dishes, and while the food is NOT top-notch, it is at least edible, and, as in the nature of most Chinese restaurants, specialize in a few dishes, while the more traditional ones are lacking in authenticity.
